div.p: (Talking/joking about darts game) NARRATOR: As alcohol or drug use becomes more central to our social lives, we gravitate to people whose drinking or drug use is similar to our own.
NARRATOR: Over time, these relationships become increasingly important which can lead to social dependence. (Talking/joking about darts game)

NARRATOR: Social dependence means our social group relies on high-risk drinking or drug use for its normal social functioning. This doesn't mean that people in the group pressure others to make high-risk choices.
NARRATOR: But it does mean that making high-risk choices is normal for any member of the group. It seems like "everybody does it." And if everybody does it, how "high-risk" can it be?

(Talking/joking about poker game) NARRATOR: So, how do you know if a group has social dependence? Try to imagine what it would be like for the group to get together without drinking high-risk amounts or using drugs.
NARRATOR: Would it feel as comfortable? Would it be as fun? You might even ask yourself, would they stay together at all? (Talking/joking about poker game)
KIRBY: Whether it was real or not there seemed to be a lot of peer presure especially to me to drink and that driking was how you had fun and that's kind of the most fun thing to do.

KIRBY: And I think people defintetly egged each other on, whether they were aware of that or not. And it was hard, you know and if people stopped drinking it was harder for them to fit in with the group, so that's...

KIRBY: It's tough to, you don't want to lose all your friends just because you stopped doing something, so that might of kept some people drinking when they didn't really want to, or they had qualms about it or they felt guilty.
KIRBY: So I think there was quite a bit of social dependancy and you know at that age we all kind of felt like it was okay and it was really normal but the fact is it's never...
KIRBY: People are not making as many high risk choices as you might think.
